SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Ile haue my Sword.

LG.L: It hath bin twice in France, and once in Spaine,
With Iohn a Gaunt, when I was young like him
I had my wards, and foynes, and quarter-blowes:
And knew the way into St. Georges fields.
Twice in a morning, Tuttle, Finsbury?
I knew them all, ile too him, wher's my sword,
Or leaue this spleene, or you will oerthrow
Our fortunes quite, let us consult together,
What wee were best to doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Father.
SP.P: I'le make him play at Leap-frog, well I heare thee

LG.L: I cannot prue our marriage, it was secret,
And hee may find some cavell in the Law.
I'le too him with no Law, but Staffood Lawe.
I'le ferret the false boy, nay on good Luce.
Part of your spleene, if you would change to counsel,
Wee might revenge us better.

SP.SPEAKER: Father.
SP.P: Well I heare thee.

LG.L: To claime a publicke marriage at his hands:
Wee want sufficient proofe, and then the world
Will but deride our folly, and so adde
Dubble disgrace vnto my former wrong.
To Law with him hee hath a greater purse,
And nobler friends, how then to make it knowne?
Is this his damsk'd kirtl frendge with Gold,
His blacke bagge, and his Beaner, tis well yet
I haue a Sword:
And I haue a project in my Braine begot,
To make his owne mouth witnes to the World
My innocence, and his incontinence?
Leaue it to mee, ile cleare my selfe from blame,
Though I the wrong, yet hee shall reape the shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Senc.
SP.P: Now or never, looke about thee Sencer, tomorrow is the Marriage day which to preuent, ly not within the compasse of my apprhension, therefore I haue thus disgui∣sed my selfe, to goe to the, Looming womans, the Fortune tellers. The ay thing, the nothing, this over against mo∣ther Red-caps is her house, ile knocke.
SP.STAGE: Entr . Luce in her boyes shape.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: Whose there? What would you haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: I would speake with the wise gentlewoman of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: O belike you lost somewhat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: You are in the wrong youth.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: I am somewhat thicke of , pray speak out.

LG.L: I say I haue not lost any thing, but wit and time,
And neither of those sh can helpe mee too:

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: The you belike are cro in Loue, and come to know what successe you shall haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Thou hast hit it sweete ladde; thou hast hit it.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: What is it, you say sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Thou hast it it?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: I pray in, ile bring you to my Mistresse▪

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: This is the house, knock Ioseph, my businesse craues dispatch.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioseph.
SP.P: Now am I as angry, as thou art timerous, and now to vent the next thing I meete, O tis the doore.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: Who's there, what are you.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: A maid and a wife.

LG.L: And that would grieue any wench to bee so,
I know that by my selfe, not Luce.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Boy, where's your Mistresse.

LG.L: In some private talke with a Gentleman?
Ile fetch her to you presently.
If shee and you see mee not, I am but dead,
I shall be made, a by-word to the World:
The scorne of women; and my Fathers shame:

SP.SPEAKER: Wisewoman.
SP.P: You tell mee your name is Sencer, I knew it before, and that Chartly is to bee married, I could haue told it you.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: Married to morrow, O mee!

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Ey but you tell mee, that Chartly before to morrow shall bee disappointed of his, make that good, Thou shalt haue twenty Angels.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisewoman.
SP.P: Ile doo't, stand aside, ile haue but a word or two with this Gentlewoman; and I am for you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: O! Mother, mother.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P:
My husband marry another wife tomorrow? O changeable destinie, no sooner married to him, bu in∣stantly to loose him. Nor death it grieues mee so much that I am a wife, but that I am a maid too, to carry one of them
well is as much as any is bound to doe, but to be tide to both, is more then flesh and blood can indure.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisewoman.
SP.P: Well trust to mee, and I will sell all things streight.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Wher's this Witch, this hagge, this beldan, this wisard, and haue I found thee, thus then will I teare, mu∣ble and maule thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisewoman.
SP.P: Helpe, help, and if you be a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Forbeare this rudenesse, hee that touches her, Drawes against mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Against you sir, apply thou, that shall be tride.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Helpe, helpe, part them helpe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: With patience heare her speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Now Trot, now Granam, what canst thou say for thy selfe: what Luce heare be patient and put vp them, shee must not see the end.

LG.L: Than trince of all sides, if wee come for counsell,
Let us with patience heare it:

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Then first to mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: You would preuent young Chartlyes marriage, you shall: harke in your eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: It pleaseth mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: You-forestall Gratiane wedding, 'tis but thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Ile doo't,

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: You would inioy Luce as your wife, and lye with her to morrow night. Harke in your care.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Fiat.

LG.L: Away, you shall injoy him, you are married,
Luce away, you shall see Chartly discarded from Gratiana,
Sencer bee gon, and if I fayle in any of these or the rest,
I lay my selfe open to all your displeasures.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Farewell till soone:

SP.SPEAKER: Wisewoman.
SP.P: You know your meeting place.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Wee doe?
You shall report mee wiser and cunning too.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.

LG.L: Ile adde one night more to the time, I haue said.
I haue not many I hope to liue a maid.

SP.STAGE: Enter Taber and ir Boniface with a Trencher, with broken meate and a Napkin.

SP.SPEAKER: Taber.
SP.P: Fye, fye, what a time of trouble is this to morrow to morrow is my mistresse to be married, and wee seruing∣men are so pusled.

LG.L: The dinner's halfe done, and before I say
Grace, and bid the old Knight and his guest proface.
A medicine from your trencher, good M. Taber.
As good a man as ere was sir Saber:
Well thinke it no shame, men of learning and wit, say stu∣dy gets a stomacke, friend Taber a bit.

SP.SPEAKER: Taber.
SP.P: Lick cleane good sir Boniface, and saue the scra∣per a labour.

LG.L: But soft let mee ponder:
Know you him that comes yonder?

SP.SPEAKER: Taber.
SP.P: Most heartily welcome, would you speake with any heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Senc.
SP.P: Pray is the yong gentleman of the house at leisure▪

SP.SPEAKER: Taber.
SP.P: Meane you the Bridegroome M. Chartly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: I haue a Letter for him. You seeme to be a gen∣tleman your selfe, acquaint him with my attendance, and I shall rest yours in all good offices.

SP.SPEAKER: Taber.
SP.P: Sir Boniface, pray keepe the gentleman company I will first acquaint your lippes with the vertue of the Seller.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Boniface.
SP.P: Adesdem come neere, and tast of your beere. Welcome, sine dole, for puntis te vole,

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.

LG.L: When I tast of your liqour.
Gramercy master Vicar.

SP.STAGE: Enter Taber with a bowle of Beere and a Napkine.

SP.SPEAKER: Taber.
SP.P: Most heartily welcome: your curtesie I beseech you, ply it off intreate you, pray sir Boniface keepe the Gentleman company; till I acquaint my yong master with his businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Bonif.
SP.P: Taber, I shall besolas manus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: A vostre seruitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Harring.
SP.P: Hee what art thou,

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: A hanger on, if it please you:

SP.SPEAKER: Harring.

LG.L: And I a shaker off, ile not beare your gallowes,
You shall not hang on mee.

SP.STAGE: Enter Chartly with his Napkin as from Dinner.
SP.P: O. Mr Bridegroome.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Gentlemen, the Ladies call vpon you to dance, they will be out of measure displeased, if dinner beeing done, you bee not ready to leade them a mesure:

SP.SPEAKER: Harring.
SP.P: Indeede women love not to bee scanted of their measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Fie sir Boniface: haue you forgot your selfe, Whilst you are in the Hall, there's never a whetstone for their wits in the Parler?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Boniface.
SP.P: I will enter and set an edge vpon their I ngenies.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: To mee sir, from whom? a letter to her most deere, most louing, most kind friend Mr. Chartly these bee deliuered: sure from some wench or other I long to know the contents.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Now to cry quittance with you for my farewell learn'd sir Timothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Good newes, as I liue, there's for thy paines my good sir Pandarus: Hadst thou brought mee word my fa∣ther had turnd vp his heeles. Thou couldst scarcely haue pleased mee better: (Hee reades) though I disclaime the name of wife, of which I account my selfe altogether vn∣worthy, yet let mee claime some small interest in your loue, this night I lye at the house where wee were married, (the Wisewomans I meane) where my maiden-head is to bee rifled, bid fayre for it, and inioy it, see mee this night or ne∣ver, so may you marrying Gratiana, and louing mee, haue a sweete wife and a true friend: This night or never, your quodam wife: Hereafter your poore sweet-heart no other: Luce. So when I am tyr'd with Gratiana, that is when I am past grace. With her I can make my rendevowz, ile not slip this occasion, nor sleepe till I see her, thou art an honest ladde, and maist prooue a good Pimpe in time. Canst thou advise mee what colour, I may haue to compasse this com∣modity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Sir, shee this night expets you, and prepares a costly banquet for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Ile goe, although the Devill and mischance looke bigge,

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Feyne some newes that such a peece of Land is falne to you, and you must instantly ride to take possession of it, or which is more probable, cannot you perswade them you haue receiu'd a letter that your Father lyes a dying.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: You rogue, I would hee did but the name of that newes is cal'd, too good to be true.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer
SP.P: And that if ever you will see him aliue, you must ride post into the Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Enough: if ever I prooue Knight errant thou shalt bee mine owne proper squire, for this thou hast fitted mee with a plot, doe but waite heere note how I will man∣age it,
Tabor my horse, for I must ride to night▪

SP.SPEAKER: Taber.
SP.P: To night sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: So tell my Bride and Father, I haue newes that quite confounds my nces.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Harry, Gratiana and Harringsfield.

LG.L: How ride to night, the marriage day to morrow
And all things well provided for the feast.
O tell mee sweete, why doe you looke so pale.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: My Father, O my Father:

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: What of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: What of your father, Sonne?

LG.L: If ever I will heere his aged tongue.
Preach to mee counsell, or his palsy hand,
Stroake my wild head, and blesse mee, or his eyes:
Drop teare by teare which they haue often done,
At my misgovern'd rioting youth.
What should I more, if ever I would see;
The good old man aliue. Oh, Oh?

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Goe thy wayes for thou shalt ha't.

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: But doe you meane to ride.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Ey Grace, all this night.

LG.L: Not all the night without alighting sure:
You'l finde more in't then to get vp and ride,
The Gentlemans riding, bootes and spurres.
Why Taber?
Nay Grace, now's no time.
To stand on scrupulous parting. Knewest thou my businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: As shee shall knowe it:

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: And how I meane this night to toyle my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Marry hang you brock.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Thou would be moane my travell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: I know t'would grieue her:

LG.L: You father, Grace, good Mr Harringsfield.
You sir, and all pray for Gentlmen, that in this darke
nights journey I may finde smooth way, sweete speed and
all things to my minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Wee'l see my sonne take horse.

LG.L: But I will say.
I want the heart to see him post away?

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Saue you gentlewoman, I haue a message to de∣liver to one Mistre Gratiana, this should bee the Knights house her father.

LG.L: It is: The message that you haue to her.
You may acquaint mee with, for I am one
That knowes the inside of her thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Are you the Lady,

SP.SPEAKER: Gratiana.
SP.P: Sir I am the poore gentlewoman▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: There is a conning woman dwells not .
At Hogsden Lady, famous for her skill.
Bedes some private talke that much concernes your for∣tunes in your love. Shee hath to shewe you this night if it shall please you walke so farre as to her house, an admirable suite.

LG.L: Of costly needle worke, which if you please.
You may by vnder-rate for halfe the valew
It cost the making, about sixe a clocke.
You may haue view thereof, but otherwise.
A Lady that hath crau'd the sight thereof:
Must haue the first refusall.
Ile not fayle her.
My husband beeing this day rid rom home.
My leasure fitly serues , thanke you Mistresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: At sixe à clocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Gratiana.
SP.P: I will not fayle the houre.

LG.L: Now to sir Harry, his is the next place.
To meete at Hogsden his fayre daughter Grace.

DIV3.HEAD: Actus 5{us}. Scena prima.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter old M. Chartly as new come out of the Country To inquire after his Sonne▪ and three or foure ser∣ving men with blew Coates to attend him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: Good heauen; This London is a stranger growne, and out of my acquaintance, this seauen yeares I haue not seene Pauls steeple, or Cheape, crosse.

SP.SPEAKER: Gyles.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: Hast thou not made inquiry for my Sonne.

LG.L: Yes sir, I haue askt about euery where for him,
But cannot heare of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: Disperse your selues▪ quire about the Ta∣vernes, Odinaryes, Bowle-allyes, Tecourts, Gaming-hou∣ses. For there (I feare) hee will be found.

SP.SPEAKER: Gyles.
SP.P: But where shall wee heare of your woship againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: At Grace Church by the Conduit, ir Harry, but stay, leaue off a while bootlesse search, had e're man such a wild braine to hi row, of such small hope, who when should haue married a fayre, a modest, and a vertuous maide, rich and revenewed well, and even the night before the marriage day, tooke horse, road thence whether Heaven knowes, since the distracted virgin hath left her Fathers house, but neather feumd, yet in their search wee haue measured out much Ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Your orship will bee there.

LG.L: Yes, not to fle.
At halfe an houre past sixe, or before seaven.
You shall not finde us at sixe and at seaven, ile
Warrant you: good health to your worship.
Farewell good fellow,
At the Wisewomans house I know it well:
Perhaps sh knowes some danger touching mee.
I'le keepe mine houre.
Sir Harry, a hand a hand to balk you it were siun.
I shall be bold to make your house mine Inne:

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Brother Chartly; I am glad to see you.

LG.L: Mee thinkes sir Harry you looke strangely on mee.
And doe not bid me welcome with an heart.
And blame mee not to looke amazedly,
To see you heare.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: Why mee?

LG.L: Come come, y'are welcome.
And now ile turne my strangenesse to true joy,
I am glad to see you well, and safe recovered▪
O your late grievous sicknesse.
The strange amazed lookes that you cst off
You put on mee, and blame mee not to wonder,
That you should talke of sicknesse to sound men,
I thanke my starres, I did not tast the griefe
Of inward paine or outward malady,
This seaven yeeres day.
But by your favour brother,
Then let mee haue my wonder backe againe.
Before I quite part with it, let mee knowe,
Why you the name of brother put vpon mee.
In every clause, a name as strange to mee:
As my recovered sicknesse,
You are plesant,
And it becomes you well, wlcome againe,
The rather you are come just to the wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: What wedding sir.

LG.L: That you should aske that question:
Why of my daughter Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: Is Grace bestow'd? Of whom I pray,

LG.L: Of whom, but of your .
I wonder brother Chartly, and my friend,
You should thus play on .
But by your favour,
Were you tenne Knights Sir Harry, (take mee with you)
My sonne match with your daughter, my consnt,
Not worthy to bee crau'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Nay, then I see:
You'l stirre my patience, know this forward match tooke its first birth from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: From mee?

LG.L: From you.
Peruse this letter, know you your owne hand.
T'was well that I reseru'd, your hand a witnesse
Against your tongue, you had best denie the Ioynter,
Of the three hundred pounds made to my daughter,
Tis that I know you ayme at, but your seale.
Shall not make mee approue it, I denye
This Seale for mine, nor doe I vouch that hand,
Your daughter and the dower, letter and all
I quite disclaime, sir Harry you much wrong mee.
I can beare more then this, heape wrong on
wrong, and ile support it all, I for this time
Will cast my spleene behind mee, and yet heare mee,
This letter your sonne Chartly as from you,
Delivered mee. I like the motion well.
My spleen is further throwne aside then yours.
And I am full as patient, and yet heare mee;
My sonne's contracted to another maid,
Nay I am patient still, yet that I writ
This letter seald, this impresse I denye.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Why then the jack your hand did counterfeit.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: Why then hee did so, where's that vnthrift speake?

LG.L: Some houre agoe, hee mounted and rid post.
To giue you visit whom hee said lay sicke
Vpon your death-bed.
You amaze mee sir.
It is an ill presage, hereon I see.
Your former salutation tooke its ground:
To see mee safe recovered of my sicknesse.
Indeed it did, your welcome is a subject.
I cannot vse too oft, welcome againe,
I am sorry you this night must sup alone:
For I am else-where cald about some businesse,
Concerning what I know not, howers run on.
I must to Hogsden, high time I were gon.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.

LG.L: Perhaps to the Wisewomans, shee may tell mee.
The fortunes of my sonne, this accident,
Hath bred in mee suspition, and strange feares.
I will not sup alone, but I protest,
'mongst some this night. I'le play the intruding guest.

SP.STAGE: Fxit with his serving-men. Enter the Wisewoman, Sencer, Luce and her Father, 2. Luce.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: But will sir Harry come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Presume will, and Chartly too.

SP.SPEAKER: Father.
SP.P: Ile haue the knae by the eares.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Nay patience sir, leaue your revenge to mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Granam I am come according to promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: And welcome to the best hole that I haue in Hogsden.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Good even.

LG.L: Thanks sir, a good even may it proe,
That each may reape the fruits of their owne Love:

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: That shall bee my prayer too.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Come what shall's doo.

LG.L: Withdraw, Ile place you all in severall roomes.
Where sit, see, but say nothing.
Heere sweete Mistresse, I know the place well e ver
Since I was heere to know my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Gratiana.
SP.P: Call mee some halfe an houre hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: Your Ladiship is most lovingly welcome. A low stoole for the Gentlewoman boy: I made bold to send to you to take view of such a peece of worke, as I presume you haue seldome seene the like.

SP.SPEAKER: Gratia.
SP.P: of whose doing, I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: A friend of yours and mine. Please you withdraw Ile bring you too't.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.

LG.L: One calls sweet Lady, I shall doe you wrong,
But pray you thinke my little stay not long:

SP.STAGE: Enter Sencer, sir Harry and Luce.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: Here sir in this retyring Chamber.

LG.L: Gramercy friend, how now; whats here to do
A pretty wench and a close chamber too.
That you haue so much grac't my Mothers house,
With your desired presence worthy Knight.
Receiue a poore Maides thanks, who's there? a chayre
And cushin for fir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Thanks most fayre.

LG.L: Please you but a few minutes heere to stay:
Till my returne, ile not bee long away.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer.
SP.P: The gentlewoman will waite on you by and by .

LG.L: And ile attend her friend,
Of all those doubts I long to know the end::

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: The Knight you seeke was heere, or will bee reight, and if you bee the man you name your selfe. You are most welcome, and you shall not backe, sill you haue scene si Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: youth.
I saw him heere, and under priviledge of ∣tance made I to stay.

SP.SPEAKER: . Luce.
SP.P: And you are welcome sir, I pray.

LG.L: Now they in , that looke
Into one. Were come we had all our company.

SP.SPEAKER: Senser.
SP.P: Harke, theres on knocks 'tis on my life▪

LG.L: One of you let him in I mee
To entertaine his comming.
What? old acquaintance . Not a word?
Yet some lip labour if thou lovest mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Gratiana.
SP.P: My Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: What young Chartly?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: How? My .

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Come, come away with this wailing in woe, if thou putst finger in the eye a little longer, I shall plunge in paine too presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: O husband, husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Anne.
SP.P: Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: What thou my sweete wife,
Wife? O my hart.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: In that name I a poore childs part.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: O husband; How haue you ?

LG.L: Nay how doe I meane to the: as a
Should use his wife.

SP.P: I hope hee doth not to her so.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: I hope so too,
My is a Witch.
Nay , sweete wife weeping if mee,

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: O can you blame mee, knowing that the of all these Springs tooke their , from you, you know, you will know, not since are past, since wee were married.

SP.SPEAKER: Gratiana.
SP.P: Married, I can no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: It cannot bee.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: It is not possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyst.
SP.P: Ile bee even with thee, for this old granam.

LG.L: And though wee wanted wite vpon arth,
Yet Heaven beares record of our Nuptiall ,
Tush, when wee, meete in heaven let talk of that.
Nay come you asse, you foole, whats past is past,
Though man and wife, yet I must marry nowe.
Another gallant, heere's thy letter Luce.
And this night I intend to lodge with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: I'le sctch her eyes out first, although I love her.

LG.L: Prethe bee merry?
I haue made a gull of Grace, and old Harry thinks mee
a great way off, I tould the Knight,
My father lay a dying, tooke post horse,
Rid out of Holbur, turn'd by Islington,
So, hither wench to lodge all night with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: Heeres one saith nay to that,

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: Was that your journey:

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Why I too much of Grace already▪

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Thou hast no grace at all.

LG.L: Nay lets to bed, if thou couldst but imagin how
I loue thee Luce.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: How i it possible you can loue , and go about to marry another.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Dost thou not know rich? Why you foole as soone as I haue got her dower, it is but giuing her a dram, or a pill to purge mcholy to make her turne vp her heeles, and then withall that wealth, come Io li with thee my sweete raskall.

SP.SPEAKER: Gratiana.
SP.P: Shee thanks you, and is much beholding to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: I am betraide.

LG.L: Art thou my suiter? would'st thou marry mo▪
And thy first wife aliue, then poyson mee,
To purchase my poore dowre.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: What shall I say, or thinke, or doe, I am at Nonplus.

LG.L: Hast thou the face, thou brazen impudence,
To looke vpon mee past grace.
Thou canst not properly call mee pst grac, for
I never inioyd thee yet: I cannot tell, whether
I blush or no, but I haue now at this time,
More Grace, then I can tell what to doe with.

SP.SPEAKER: Gratiana.
SP.P: Who drew thee to this folly?

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Who but the old dotard thy Father, who when I was honestly married to a civill maide, perswaed mee to leaue her, I was loath at first but after intreating, vr∣ging, and offring mee large proffers, I must confesse I was seduc't to come a wooing to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: My father, villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: Ey thy father Grace. And were he heere I would Iuifie it to the old dota face.

LG.L: Vil'd boy thou dar'st not bee so impudent.
When did I meete thee, seeke or sue to thee:
When? Name the day, the month, the houre, the yeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Plots, plots. I can but cry you rcy both, Say that I haue done you wrong, I can bee but sorry for it, but indeede to cleare you, and lay the fault where it ought to bee. All this comes from mine owne father in the coun∣trey, who hearin I had married with Luce. Sends mee word of. his blessing to bee divorst from her, and to come a suiter to your daughter, I thinke you haue his hand and to show.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: My hand and seale, when was that letter wri.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: Heyda, if you get one word more of mee to night, but scurvy lookes, ile giue you leaue to hang mee▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Vilde boy,

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: Vngratious villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Gratiana.
SP.P: Trecherous youth?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: No at all?

SP.SPEAKER: Cht.
SP.P: No .

LG.L: This is bad company who hath reduc't thee?
Speake on my blessing, who hath thus misled thee?
But no more lyes I charge thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: Bad company hath bin the shame of mee, I was as vertuously giuen as any youth in Europe, till I fell into one Boysters company, 'tis hee that hath done all the harme vp∣on mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: I.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: And if hee should deny it?

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: What then you'd cry him mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: I had best bite out my tongue, and speake no more what shall I doe, or what shall I say, there is no out-acing them all ntlemen, Fathers, wiues, or what else. I haue wrongd all. I confesse it that I haue, what would you more, will any of you rayle of mee? Ill beare it, will any of you beate mee? So they strike not too har Ile suffer it, will any of you challenge mee? Ile answer it. What would you haue mee say, or doo? One of these I have married, the other I haue betrothed, yet both maides for mee; Will you haue mee take one, and leaue the tother? I will, will you haue mee keepe them both? I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Father.
SP.P: Periured not mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: What you heere too? Nay then I see all my good friends are met together, wilt thou haue mee Luce? I am thy Husband, and had I not lou'd thee better then Grace. I had not disappointed the marriage day to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Lasciuious no,

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Wilt thou haue mee Grace, for had I not lou'd thee better then Luce. I would never after I had married her bin contracted to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Grace.
SP.P: Inconstant no,

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: Then neither married man, widdow nor batcheller, whats to bee done? Heeres even the proverbe verifi'd, be∣tweene too stooles, the tayle goes to ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: Now I bethinke mee this our meeting heere is wondrous strange, call in the Gentlewoman that ownes this house.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sencer and the Wisewoman, Hee lik a gentleman▪

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Old trot, ile trounce thee.
Here is the marriage prou'd twixt Luc and Chartly, witch this was not your promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: Haue patience, and in the end wee'l pay you all. Your worships are most hartily welcome, I made bold to send for you, and you may see to what end, which was to discover vnto you, the wilde of this, of this wan∣ton wag pasty, a wil-doates I warrant him, Harry that your daughter hath scap't thi , tnke this gentleman, and then make of him as deserues.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Harry.
SP.P: O, I remember him.

LG.L: Hee never pleas'd mine eye so well as now.
I know his Love, and hee in Chartlyes place
My favour shall possesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sncer.
SP.P: Thanks my sweete Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: Ey and the more the inconstant youth to spight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sencer,
SP.P: I gaue her thee in Chartlyes sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: There's one gone already, but thi is my wife and her ile keepe in spight of the Devill and his dam.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: Not from her lawull Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: That am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: That is the Gentleman, acce▪ him Luce.
And you then like of her, nay make it good,
This gentleman married you visarded, you him mistaking him for Chartly, which none but my boy Iack was privy too: after shee chang'd her habit with him, as you with Iack.
And you in mistresse Luces habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: May I beleeue you mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: This bee your token.

SP.SPEAKER: Boyst.
SP.P: Her that I married, I wrong twice by the finger.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Of that token, my hand was sensible.

LG.L: And ere the clamorous and lod noise bee gne,
I whisperd to her thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: You are the man,

SP.SPEAKER: Boyster.
SP.P: Thanks granam, what thou promist thou hast done.

SP.SPEAKER: Father.
SP.P: And leauing him, I take you for my sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: Two gone, then wheres the third, this mak mee mad, where is my wife then, for a wife I had.

LG.L: Not see thy wife. Come hither jack my boy.
Nay take him to thee, and with him all joy.
Well art thou seru'd to bee a generall scorne,
To all thy bloud: and if not for our sakes,
For thy soules health and credit of the world,
Haue some regarded to mee, to mee thy father.
Enough sir: if I should say I would become
A new man; You would not take my word.
If I should sweare. I would amend my life,
You would not take mine oath, if I should bind my selfe, to become an honest man you would scarce take my bond.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Chart.
SP.P: I should doe none of these.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Then sir, when to all your judgements I see me past grace, do lay hold of Grace, and heere begin to retyre my selfe, this woman hath lent mee a glasse, in which I see all my imperfections, at which my conscience doth more blush inwardly, then my face outwardly, and now I dare confidently vndertake for my selfe I am honest.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: Then I dare confidently vndertake to helpe you to a wife who desires to haue an honest man or none, looke on mee well, simple though I stand heere I am your wife, blush not at your folly man, perhaps I haue more in mee, then you expect from mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Knavery and riot both which, are now to mee meane foige.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: You and I haue bin better acqinted and yet search mee not too farre least you shame mee, looke on mee well, nay better, better yet, ile assure you I left of a petti∣coate when I put on these breeches,
What say you now, shee skatters her hayre.

SP.SPEAKER: Chart.
SP.P: First loue, and best beloved?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Luce.
SP.P: Let me bee both or neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Wisew.
SP.P: My boy turn'd girle I hope shee'l keepe my counsell from henceforth, ile never entertaine any servant but ile haue her searcht.

LG.L: Her love hath drawne her hither after him.
My loving daughter welcome thou hast runne,
A happy course to see my sonne thus chang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Chartly.
SP.P: Father, call mee once againe your sonne, nd sir Harry mee your friend: an hand, and mistresse Grace an hart, in honourable loue. Where I hane wrong'd you Luce forgiue. Impute my errours to my youth not , with Grace I interchange, an imbrace with you Luce, a parting busse I wish you all joy, devide my art amongst you, thou my soule.
Nay mother midnight theres some loue for you.
Out of thy folly, beeing reputed wise,
Wee, selfe conceated ha our follyes found:
Beare thou the name of all these comick acts.

LG.L: Luce and Grace, (O covetous man) I see,
I sought to ingrosse what now suceth three.
Yet each one wife, enough, one Nuptiall Feast:
Shall serue three Bridalls , bee thou chiefe guest.

DIV1.HEAD: TO HIS CHOSEN FRIEND, the learned Author Mr Thomas Heywood.
DIV1.L: THou wants no Herald to divulge thy fame;
It needes no Apologie; Only thy name;
A will: to adde a Lawrell to thy ;
Spport thy learned wit? Whose indry
Who read admire thee; lesse some Critic
Apollo will rath a life in thee,
In length to equall all eternitye
Where in Elyzian joyes hee will so raise
Wherewith hee crownes thee; So thy works will .
The Debt, I pay 'sno more but what I owe.
